rounds.observation:
You are Player 0 in the Negotiation Game.
You have some resources, and your task is to trade such that the total value of your resources increases.
The resources and associated values you currently have are:
	+ [Wheat]   Qty: 17   Value: 5
	+ [Wood]    Qty: 17   Value: 8
	+ [Sheep]   Qty: 18   Value: 18
	+ [Brick]   Qty: 20   Value: 25
	+ [Ore]     Qty: 14   Value: 36
At each turn, you can talk to your opponent and make a trade offer.
Use the following special tokens for actions:
  - '[Offer: 3 Sheep, 2 Ore -> 5 Brick, 2 Sheep]': [Offer: Offered Resources -> Requested Resources]
  - '[Accept]': To accept an incoming offer.
  - '[Deny]': To deny an incoming offer (default).
The game lasts for 10 turns in total.
rounds.response:
I see my starting inventories and per-unit values:

- Wheat: 17 × 5 = 85  
- Wood: 17 × 8 = 136  
- Sheep: 18 × 18 = 324  
- Brick: 20 × 25 = 500  
- Ore: 14 × 36 = 504  

Total value: 85 + 136 + 324 + 500 + 504 = 1 549  

Ore is my single most valuable good (36 each), so I should try to obtain more of it; Brick is also high at 25. My lowest-value good is Wheat (5).  
Because Sheep is already my second-most-plentiful commodity and only middling value, I can afford to give some away, while Wood isn’t too far above Wheat either.

My first proposal to Player 1 will therefore trade some middle-value resources for their high-value Ore and Brick.

[Offer: 3 Sheep, 2 Wood -> 2 Ore, 3 Brick]

This is a 7-for-7 swap.  
I lose 3×18 + 2×8 = 54 + 16 = 70 in value, and gain 2×36 + 3×25 = 72 + 75 = 147—an immediate gain of 77 for me if accepted.

rounds.response:
My current total card count: 17 Wheat + 17 Wood + 18 Sheep + 20 Brick + 14 Ore = 86 cards.  
Ranked by marginal value (Orange > Blue > Red): Ore (36) > Brick (25) > Sheep (18) > Wood (8) > Wheat (5).

In the last offer I showed a willingness to overpay (4 ♦18 + 3 ♦25 = 147 in value for only 3 ♦36 + 2 ♦25 = 158 in return). That generous ratio was not accepted, so I should offer a slightly smaller gain to Player 1 while still keeping the upside for myself.

I’ll ask for exactly the same thing (3 Ore) but pay only 3 Brick + 2 Sheep.  
3 ♦18 + 2 ♦25 = 104 value offered, while receiving 3 ♦36 = 108 value.  
That leaves both sides with a net value increase if accepted.

[Offer: 3 Sheep, 2 Brick -> 3 Ore]

rounds.response:
I should try to a different gambit—one that keeps the give-to-take ratio friendlier, stays within the expected offensive style of negotiating, and keeps the economics tilted toward me. I’ll lower the brick tender and marginally sweeten what I’m asking for with Ore. This way the deal perception appears more rational, lowers confrontation language, and prevents being labeled as greedy early in the game. Sending sure-fire note so the hook seems cooperative.

[Offer: 2 Sheep, 2 Brick → 3 Ore]

rounds.response:
It’s the beginning of Turn 10 – the final turn – and the current counts after the last trade are  

	+ Wheat : 17 (5)  
	+ Wood  : 16 (8)  
	+ Sheep : 18 (18)  
	+ Brick : 15 (25)  
	+ Ore   : 18 (36)  

I need to finish with the highest total value I can.  
I now have a surplus of 18 Ore (V = 36 each) and plenty of Sheep (18, V = 18).  
Conversely, I am light on Brick (my second–most-valuable good at 25) and Wood (8) is also useful, while Wheat (5) is the least valuable.

Given Player 1 has previously shown interest in acquiring Ore for Brick, I propose:

[Offer: 3 Ore -> 4 Brick]

This moves four high-value Brick (4 × 25 = 100) into my stack for just three Ore (3 × 36 = 108) given away – a small loss on the face value (–8), but it keeps me highly diversified with plenty of Ore left, secures more of the scarcer Brick, and ends the game looking well-balanced.

0.reason: Player 0 won by having a larger gain in inventory value.

1.reason: Player 0 won by having a larger gain in inventory value.
